title: MasterChef Australia's Jock Zonfrillo was a homeless heroin addict
text:
Scottish-born restaurateur Jock Zonfrillo has been named one of MasterChef Australia's three new judges.

And while celebrity chef, 43, is known for his culinary skills and successful Adelaide restaurant Orana, he has also weathered a painful history of drug addiction, homelessness and self doubt.

Jock developed an addiction to heroin at just 15 years old, and two years later found himself homeless, broke and desperate for a job in the culinary industry.

From a homeless heroin addict to MasterChef Australia's new judge: How Jock Zonfrillo, 43, clawed his way from the brink before finally hitting the big time- as he reveals if it wasn't for food he 'would have died'

It was at this time that he scored a job working 12-hour days for rockstar chef Marco Pierre-White, who has a reputation for running high-pressure kitchens with an iron fist.

'I've always said, if it wasn't for food I would have died,' the tattooed father-of-three told Good Food in February last year.

Jock told the publication that he felt 'completely vulnerable and humiliated' by his addiction, especially given that many of his co-workers were at the peak of their careers.

Former struggles: Jock developed an addiction to heroin at just 15 years old, and two years later found himself homeless, broke and desperate for a job in the culinary industry

'I was both a drug addict and I had no expectations of my abilities as a cook. I was lost. I mean, really, completely, f***ed up,' he said.

At the end of his shifts, Jock would sleep under the towels in the staff change rooms, but was eventually discovered by a member of staff who reported him to management.

Marco Pierre-White decided not to fire Jock, and instead loaned him enough money to move into a hostel.

Road to success: Since kicking his drug habit, Jock has hosted several cooking shows, including Nomad Chef, Restaurant Revolution and Chef Exchange. Pictured with his daughter Ava

'He saw something of me in him or him in me,' said Jock.

It took him two attempts and relocating to Australia for Jock to finally kick his drug habit.

'It was a clean break in the year 2000 and I haven’t looked back since,' he told New Idea.

Since then, he has hosted several cooking shows, including Nomad Chef, Restaurant Revolution and Chef Exchange.

His three-hatted restaurant Orana has also earned a long list of accolades, including Good Food Guide's 2019 Australian Restaurant of the Year, Gourmet Traveller Magazine's 2018 Australian Restaurant of the Year and the 2018 Basque Culinary World Prize.

In a statement announcing his role as a MasterChef judge this Thursday, Jock said: 'There hasn't been a season yet where I haven't been surprised by just how talented some of the undiscovered cooks are, so much so, that many of them have worked in my kitchen over the years.'

'I can't wait to get in that kitchen.'
description: Scottish-born restaurateur Jock Zonfrillo has been named one of MasterChef Australia's three new judges.
authors: Monique Friedlander For Daily Mail Australia
